Problem:
Consider a linear system of equations represented by \\(Ax = b\\), where \\(A\\) is a matrix and \\(b\\) is a vector. We introduce a transformation \\(T(x) = Mx\\) where \\(M\\) is also a matrix that modifies the system prior to solving for \\(x\\).

If the transformation \\(T(x) = Mx\\) is applied to the system before solving for \\(x\\), will the solution \\(x\\) of the modified system \\(A(Mx) = b\\) be equivalent to the direct solution of the original system \\(Ax = b\\)?
Explanation: The transformation \\(Mx\\) will generally modify the system of equations, leading to a different effective system \\(AMx = b\\). Unless \\(M\\) is the inverse of \\(A\\) or commutes specifically with \\(A\\) to simplify back to \\(Ax = b\\), the solution will not be the same.
